RetroTech Consulting Group

We help businesses integrate obsolete office technology into modern workflows — not because it's efficient, but because efficiency was never the point. For seven years we've been installing Wang word processors in coworking spaces and training interns on telex protocol, because somewhere between the cloud migration and the fourth Slack channel, work stopped making a sound you could trust. This is a consulting firm. This is also, if we're being honest, a memorial service.

Co-founded with Esmerelda Stern, 2017. She's in Reno now. The modems remember.

The Unexpected Renaissance of Dot Matrix Printing: Why Your Memos Should Sound Like a Robot Crying

At RetroTech, we advise clients to reintroduce impact printing into their document workflows — not as novelty, not as branding exercise, but as a genuine productivity intervention. The objections are predictable. "It's slower." Yes. "The output looks archaic." Correct. "My team will think I've lost my mind." Almost certainly. But consider: the average knowledge worker sends 47 digital communications per day and remembers the content of none of them. A dot matrix memo, by contrast, announces itself from two rooms away.

The physics matter here. An impact printer works by firing a vertical column of pins — typically 9 or 24 — against an ink-soaked ribbon, pressing each character into the page through literal force. The paper doesn't receive the text; it absorbs the impact. Each letter is a tiny controlled collision, 150 Hertz of contact between intention and medium. There's no buffer. No print queue purgatory. The document exists the moment the pin strikes, and everyone within earshot knows it. You can hear a dot matrix printer thinking, which is more than you can say for most of what happens in a modern office.

Esmerelda understood this before I did. She used to say the sound of a dot matrix printer was "the last honest sound in an office — the sound of a machine that couldn't pretend it wasn't working." I thought she was being poetic. She was being precise. She's in Reno now, building something with modems, and I'm here, still loading tractor-feed paper like it means something. It does.

"We hired RetroTech to install a telex machine in our open-plan office. Productivity dropped 12%. Morale increased immeasurably. For the first time in six years, people looked up from their screens when someone had something to say. I don't know what we lost when we got fast, but I felt it come back."
— Patricia Voss, COO, Voss & Meridian Supply Chain Partners
"Barnaby set up a Wang terminal in our conference room. My board thought it was a joke. Then our lead engineer typed a proposal on it — slowly, deliberately, each word chosen because backspace was expensive — and it was the clearest memo anyone had written in a decade. Cryptic? Maybe. Effective? Baron Von Richter doesn't use that word lightly."
— Baron Klaus Von Richter, Founder, Von Richter Aerospace Consulting
"They put a Rolodex on every desk. My sales team laughed. Then the CRM went down for three days and the only people still closing deals were the ones who'd actually written the numbers down. We've kept the Rolodexes. We've also kept the CRM, but nobody trusts it anymore, which feels like progress."
— Juniper Blackwell, VP Sales, Halcyon Data Brokers Inc.
